misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay aligned when sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array (z) will automatically reorder the names array (y) in the same way, so that y[i] will still refer to the student who has score z[i] after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent containers. Arrays.sort(z) rearranges only the elements inside z; it does not (and cannot) automatically apply the same permutation to y. To keep name-score pairs aligned, you must swap elements in both arrays together during sorting, or use an object/record (e.g., Student{name,score}) and sort that.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints the correct maximum score (after sorting z) but an incorrect name (y[n-1] is just the last input name, not the name of the max score).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array (scores) will automatically rearrange the elements of another array (names) to maintain the relationship between them, as if the two arrays were inherently linked by their indices.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. The Arrays.sort() method only manipulates the memory of the specific array passed to it. It has no awareness of parallel data structures, meaning any index-based association between 'names' and 'scores' is destroyed when only one array is sorted.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Stay Aligned When Sorting One Array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `scores` array will also reorder the corresponding `names` array in the same way (or that the association between `y[i]` and `z[i]` is preserved automatically after sorting `z`).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `String[] y` and `int[] z` are independent arrays. `Arrays.sort(z)` only rearranges the elements inside `z`. Java does not know that `y[i]` is meant to be tied to `z[i]`, so it will not reorder `y` to match. To keep pairs aligned, you must swap elements in both arrays together during sorting, or use a combined structure (e.g., an array of objects/records) and sort that.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints the last name entered (original `y[n-1]`) with the highest score (sorted `z[n-1]`), producing a mismatched name-score pair.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Index-Based Pairing Assumed After Mutation of One Array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that after `z` is sorted, using the same index `n-1` on both arrays (`y[n-1]` and `z[n-1]`) still refers to the same student record, as if each index represents a permanent 'row' of a table.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: An index only refers to “whatever value is currently stored at that position.” Once you reorder only `z`, the meaning of each index in `z` changes, while the meaning of each index in `y` does not. Thus `y[n-1]` remains the last-entered name, but `z[n-1]` becomes the maximum score, so the printed pair is not a real student.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output even though the maximum score is correctly found at `z[n-1]` after sorting: the name does not belong to that score.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when sorting one array in a parallel array structure, the corresponding elements in the other array will automatically shift to maintain their pairing. They assume that calling Arrays.sort(z) will somehow cause the names in array y to rearrange in tandem so that each name stays with its corresponding score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student misunderstands how Arrays.sort() works. When you call Arrays.sort(z), it sorts ONLY the z array independently. The y array is not affected at all. The indices no longer correspond after sorting—the score at index 2 (92) is now Bob's score, but the name at index 2 is still Charlie (from the original position). To maintain parallel array correspondence, you must apply identical swaps to both arrays simultaneously, or use a different approach such as sorting by index positions or using objects to pair data together.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: The program outputs 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)'. The highest score (92) is correctly identified, but it's paired with the wrong name because the parallel arrays became desynchronized after sorting.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array (scores) will automatically rearrange the corresponding elements in a second array (names) because they were populated at the same indices.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, parallel arrays are distinct objects with no intrinsic link. Functions like Arrays.sort() operate only on the target array. Sorting one array while leaving the other untouched destroys the relationship between the data points at index 'i'.
